text.p: These are leading stories in this morning's Paris newspapers.
LES ECHOS
-- Bank of France 1996 net profit down 12 percent over 1995 at 1.21 billion francs.
-- Credit Lyonnais economists factor strong dollar into forecasts and predict 2.2 percent French GDP growth for 1997, up from 1.9 percent in previous forecast.
-- European Commissioner Mario Monti says member states cannot avoid the problem of differing VAT rates and fears more "fiscal dumping".
-- Government's sale of 25 to 30 percent of France Telecom should net 45 to 54 billion francs.
-- Government accounting office notes "serious discrepancies" in accounts of state-owned nuclear materials maker Cogema.
-- Aircraft engine maker CFM picks up $1.1 billion U.S. defence contract.
-- Rumours of cabinet reshuffle or dissolution of parliament continue unabated.
LA TRIBUNE

-- Government targets 260 billion franc deficit for 1998 budget as Finance Minister Jean Arthuis defends upcoming change in the legal status of Caisses d'Epargne that could net the government about 30 billion francs if such a transfer can be engineered to win approval from Brussels.
-- Brussels approves final billion franc subsidy to Air France.
-- Airbus announces orders for a total of 13 twin-engine A330-200s from Sabena and Swissair .
-- Elf and Total preparing stock buy-back schemes for 15 and 6.2 percent of share capital respectively.
-- Societe Generale voting stake in Peugeot now over five percent.
LE FIGARO

-- President's office says rumours of cabinet reshuffle or parliamentary dissolution are "groundless" as opinion polls report 41 percent of voters are for early elections and predict the defeat of the current majority.
LE FIGARO-ECONOMIE
-- Finance ministry calls for enquiry to explain 30 billion franc shortfall in 1996 VAT revenue. Intra-European fraud and off-the-books business seen as likely culprits.
-- Paris remains non-committal about Michel Camdessus candidacy for top slot at European central bank.
-- Lyonnaise des Eaux gets 18 billion franc contract from Casablanca for water and electricity supplies over 30 years.
LIBERATION
-- Conservatives reluctant to dissolve parliament which Prime Minister Alain Juppe is said to favour in order to go ahead with new autsterity measures in the run-up to the single currency.
LIBERATION (Economic section)
-- French budget outlook report says budget deficit could reach 3.8 percent of GDP this year without new measures.
THE INTERNATIONAL HERALD TRIBUNE
-- France Telecom shares to be priced at a discount to other European telecom companies because of concern over labour laws that restrict lay-offs.
